Package edu.ncsu.csc316.dsa.priority_queue

Class HeapPriorityQueue<K extends java.lang.Comparable<K>,​V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc316.dsa.priority_queue.AbstractPriorityQueue<K,​V>
      • edu.ncsu.csc316.dsa.priority_queue.HeapPriorityQueue<K,​V>
  • Type Parameters:
    K - the type of keys (priorities) stored in the priority queue
    V - the type of values that are associated with keys in the priority queue
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    PriorityQueue<K,​V>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    HeapAdaptablePriorityQueue
    public class HeapPriorityQueue<K extends java.lang.Comparable<K>,​V>
extends AbstractPriorityQueue<K,​V>
    A HeapPriorityQueue is an array-based min-heap implementation of the PriorityQueue abstract data type. HeapPriorityQueue ensures a O(logn) worst-case runtime for insert and deleteMin. HeapPriorityQueue ensures a O(1) worst-case runtime for min, size, and isEmpty. The HeapPriorityQueue class is based on an implementation developed for use with the textbook: Data Structures and Algorithms in Java, Sixth Edition Michael T. Goodrich, Roberto Tamassia, and Michael H. Goldwasser John Wiley and Sons, 2014
    Author:
    Dr. King, Tung Tran

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      HeapPriorityQueue()
      Constructs a new HeapPriorityQueue that compares keys (priorities) using the natural ordering of the key type
      HeapPriorityQueue​(java.util.Comparator<K> comparator)
      Constructs a new HeapPriorityQueue using a custom comparator

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method Description
      PriorityQueue.Entry<K,​V> deleteMin()
      Removes and returns the entry with the lowest priority in the priority queue.
      PriorityQueue.Entry<K,​V> insert​(K key, V value)
      Inserts a new entry into the priority queue with the given key (priority) and value
      PriorityQueue.Entry<K,​V> min()
      Returns (but does not remove) the entry with the lowest priority in the priority queue.
      int size()
      Returns the number of entries stored within the priority queue
